A few minutes later, the manager was looming over me, asking "were there problems with the food ?" I replied yes food was served lukewarm, so it got cold on the plate. He replied "you have been rude to my staff so I am asking you to leave." I replied that I was by no means rude, but I had questions about the coravin and when asked I told a server my food was cold.

Moral of the story: BRAT is now a tourist joint where a customer dare not complain. Chef Parry makes nice food, but his staff is entitled, lazy and do not understand the concept of hospitality. I will be pleased to never return
to BRAT.

Name: Brat
Review_Text:
brat has a real WOW factor and is most definitely where you will find the young, hip crowd. It is a place to be seen, and the communal dining environment lends itself to that. Our table for two was a row of 4 or 5 double tables, which is great for eyeing what others have ordered but not so great for quiet conversation.

The restaurant itself is located off the beaten path and really beautiful on the inside, in that hip, cool kind of way.

Like the wonderful people who grace the UK, service was warm and gracious. The menu is interesting and there really does seem to be something for everyone.

We shared -

- Grilled bread and anchovy. Comes to the table as a beautiful, bulbous piece of bread that quickly deflates once you cut into it. There were 4 or so strips of anchovies on top, but I really would have loved some in the filling.

- Spider Crab and tomato. My niece found this to be one of her favorite dishes at brat. Personally, I found the crab to be quite fishy but admittedly, it is not my favorite crustacean. If you love crab, order it. If not, perhaps a pass.

- Fresh chorizo. You look at the photo I posted and you may say, heck, there's a lot of fat in that chorizo. Well, yes. It's fatty, incredibly tasty and wonderfully delicious. We loved it.

- Langoustine. While we expected a small portion (it only costs 8 pounds!), there was so little meat it was a very disappointing dish. Particularly because the meat you did get was such a sweet treat.

- Menai Oysters with tomato & seaweed. We ordered 4, I ate 1. My niece and I love oysters and I typically devour them. These were not our favorites. With that said, full transparency, I was not a fan of the oysters I ate in the UK. All good in that there were plenty of things I really did enjoy!

- Lamb chops. We ordered two and they were absolutely perfectly cooked and delicious. If I were to go back to brat at some point I would likely order 2 of these chops for myself.

- John Dory. I've heard of John Dory/St. Peter's fish for years, but never had the opportunity to order it. When I saw it on the menu I knew it was a must-have. Sorry for no photo, but it's not the prettiest fish ;) The fish is served whole and the easiest way to get to the meat is to lift the bone out (I didn't figure that out early enough in the process). The fish itself was utterly delicious and I now know that I love John Dory. With that said, even being a whole fish, just didn't seem like a heck of a lot of meat.

I believe over the course of dinner we had a total of 4 glasses of wine. The total cost of our bill (tips are included) was $240.86, which I actually found quite reasonable.

brat has oodles of positive reviews, so take mine for what it is worth. The food actually shines in its simplicity which is something I personally love as I'm not a big fan of hiding under too much sauce/gravy. For me, dishes were hit or miss. You may love it as many of its fans do.

Name: Brat
Review_Text: Brat is a Michelin-starred basque restaurant in Shoreditch. Although space is a bit cramped, the food, wine list and service are great. Order a number of smaller plates to share so you get a full sense of the range of food and tastes of the Basque region.

Name: Brat
Review_Text: A near religious experience. One of my favorite restaurants I've tried in London after being so hyped up by the press. The restaurant itself is an open-kitchen concept with a focus on wood-fired cooking. Each dish was executed with such attention to detail but the basque cheesecake was truly what set the experience apart. And pricing was so fair for what it's worth.

Name: Brat
Review_Text:
The service was incredibly slow. No one came to check up on our table for most of the dinner. We did not have one dedicated server and instead had to call to numerous people. Flagging our waiter down in this particular restaurant is especially chaotic given how loud it is and how close you are to other people. The restaurant has a very crowded feel, which would be fine if we felt we were regularly being checked in on.

The food was not properly salted at all. The most egregious dish is the duck rice. Most of the rice we received was overcooked and firmly stuck to the pan. The duck and rice tasted bland.

Name: Brat
Review_Text: Too many flaws - a good restaurant fairly reasonably priced - lamb and beef dishes seem to be what they do best - Fantastic lamb and sweet bread dish and a great tartare - all else so so - noisy and cramped - servers try hard but it's tough layout

Name: Brat
Review_Text:
The food here was delicious. Almost everything we ordered was extremely tasty, and I thought the food was both well prepared and well plated.

I am not super happy. We were seated almost a full hour after our reservation, which meant we ended up, leaving the restaurant over two hours beyond when we were supposed to be seated. With a little one in tow, this meant bedtime was pushed back and he was cranky.

The servers also weren't very accessible, and some of them were downright rude. When we asked to order more food, they gave us a condescending "you've had quite enough" vibe. We finished all of our food for the record!

I think this would be a great date spot, or place for young couples. Not very family friendly.

Name: Brat
Review_Text: This was our first meal in our first our first night in London. We had seen it featured on somebody feed Phil, so we came to check it out ourselves. This was every bit worth the hype. Unfortunately, we didn't order the turbot because they warned us it would be too much for two people, but everything we did order was fantastic. My favorite thing was the scallop - I love scallops and order them often but this was probably the best scallop I've ever had. The char and flavor were perfect. We also ordered the toast with onion butter, red pepper side dish, crab on toast, and sirloin. I would recommend it all. Our waitress was also very friendly and gave us great recommendations. If I'm ever back in London, I'd love to come back here.

Name: Brat
Review_Text:
One of my favorite meals I've ever had in my life. Such a great variety of flavors with super friendly service and in a super cool space.

Had their special of the day, the langoustines which were absolutely delightful. Super fresh seafood

Name: Brat
Review_Text:
Wow. Such a great meal at brat. Didn't know what to expect, but from start to finish the food was excellent and the attentiveness and service of the staff was the best. Really enjoyed the oyster and chorizo bites. The real standout was the crab soup... warm, seafoody and complex, this was truly a special dish. Sardine bread was also excellent. Even the grilled bread was excellent.

Thanks brat for the best meal I had on this trip to London.

Name: Brat
Review_Text: I visited on my vacation and came after watching a Conde Naste Youtube video. I suppose I expected more since this place has a Michelin star. The restaurant is small but hip and open. The food wasn't anything to write home about. I was only impressed by the crab soup since the seafood flavor was intense. I got the grilled fish and it was okay. I wish there was more texture to it.

Name: Brat
Review_Text: I didn't like brat unfortunately. Very Smokey inside which made it hard for me to breathe. Was quite expensive so that's disappointing since I didn't like anything I ordered, including drinks.

Name: Brat
Review_Text:
A friend and I found this gem while strolling around near our hotel.

This was one of the best accidental finds in my life. Every single item ordered from the menu was incredible. The service and staff were friendly, helpful and so generous with their time explaining the dishes.

In fact, our server even took the time to explain where our next stop should be after dinner. Gave us directions and who to ask for.

The next time I'm in London; I'll make it a point to go back. You will not be disappointed.

Name: Brat
Review_Text:
Honestly, would just return for the cheesecake.

The grilled bread with green garlic was good but very oily on top. Well baked and tasty, feel like it would be better on the side of something. The lamb was not great. So fatty that it was not appealing, and not much flavor to it.

The cheesecake though... maybe the best cheesecake I've ever had. Soft and rich, almost like a custard on the very middle, but fluffy on the outer parts. Truly phenomenal. But I don't get the rhubarb on the side. It adds nothing, and is not particularly flavorful on its own either.

Name: Brat
Review_Text: The small plates here really stood out. House made chorizo could have been my favorite. Grilled bread w chanterelles was awesome. They really do bread well here. Leeks + cheese good. Tartare good. Shared a big fish that was fun to pick at and I know its one of the specialties but I think I liked the small dishes more. A group of 4-6 here vs a party of 2 would be ideal. Can try so many more items. Need reservation.

Name: Brat
Review_Text:
In my research on where I was going to go during my trip to London, I stumbled upon Brat. A one Michelin Starred joint that exclusively cooks with fire. No electricity. Just fire. From my table, I could see a massive, wood-burning oven and a giant firepit with grates at three different height levels, presumably for different heat intensities. I've heard of places like this, and I was excited to try one out for myself.

We started off with the Grilled Bread (with Girolles & Berkswell). We saw them throw it in the oven, bake right in front of our eyes, and then get adorned with some cheese and the mushrooms. A slight char, flavorful, salty cheese, and the umami from the mushrooms made this a true banger.

We ordered a small plate next, the Lamb Chop with Grilled Sweetbreads. The lamb chop had that same, good char. Tender and simply seasoned. Served with a couple of sweetbreads, which, if you've never had, you should. They are officially a new texture for me, a slight creaminess. Very unique. Very delicious.

Then we ordered a main, the Lemon Sole. A whole fish, face and all, trapped in a cage and roasted over the fire. Charred, barely seasoned, the meat singing its own praises. There aren't a lot of experiences as visceral as eating a whole fish. Amazing. FYI, though, this fish had both more and smaller pin bones that you average fish, so you're gonna work for your prize.

Then we got another main, the Roast Duck Rice. This dish was unbelievable. The rice was cooked in the duck fat, the duck was ultra crispy, and the whole mushrooms and slices of onion just made this campfire-like dish so unctuous. Very heavy, with no relief, in a good way.

With all our food, we got a couple of sides, the Smoked Potatoes and the Wood Roasted Greens. Both great. Buttery potatoes served whole, so you get that pop of the skin with every bite. The stuff of dreams. And the green were nice. Not like, mega delicious, but you need that freshness to break up the heaviness of the whole meal. It was covered in that same cheese that was on the bread. A good side.

Then it was time for dessert, the Burnt Cheesecake & Nectarine. The cheesecake was pure velvet. Amazing. It was covered with a fine layer of ash on top, which sounds not good, but it was very good. I think the one I had was served with a pear, as opposed to the new menu version, but either way, a slice of fruit complements this well, because the flavor is very neutral. Overall, great.

Overall, I loved this place. Everything they served looked so dang rustic, like it was served to me at a campsite, right out of the fire. But at the same time, it was delicate, and worthy of Michelin's attention. I also liked the way they highlighted various ingredients. The same mushrooms and cheeses kept showing up in their different dishes in different ways, and they played a good part. Yes, come here. It's a winner.

Name: Brat
Review_Text:
Really disappointing. The scallop and the leek with fresh cheese were great, but we also ordered live lobster, the beef rib, and also asked the somm for a bottle of wine and they were all very disappointing.

The lobster (76 pounds!) was small and was not fresh. We often eat lobster and eating it in Chinatown or Dishoom is way more fresh and cheaper.

We asked for the rib to be cooked medium and parts of the massive rib (over 90 pounds!) were way over that it was chewy and dry. The flavor of the steak was good but cooked poorly, and it was soaking in this weird sauce that was unnecessary. We also ordered the mushroom dish which was not delicious.

The bottle of wine suggested by the somm (65 pounds) was not memorable or delicious. Just any table wine but costs more.

Very disappointed. We can New Year's Eve. Didn't care that we had to wait for the food but was not good for the price.

Name: Chez Bruce
Review_Text: This place is just fantastic! Haven't been in years and it continues to be excellent. The cooking is exceptional, the service on point, wine list great and cocktails perfect. It has a star and not hard to see why. Yet it's totally unpretentious. You could go for a date, with friends (as long as they're fine w the slightly elevated price) or family. It's so flexible. Highly recommend.

Name: Chez Bruce
Review_Text:
Chez Bruce is a modern French restaurant in a lively area of South London, I went here for a late Mother's Day blowout.

The service is exceptional, glass top ups were frequent as were offers for more bread and snacks in between courses. Staff are very friendly and accommodating and in absolutely no rush to turn over tables. The ambience grew in stature as the afternoon aged, staring off very quiet to then becoming delightfully lively an hour or so into our sitting.

We tried a variety of food and wine, all of which were faultless - some of the things we had are pictured. It was a pricey lunch but for me fully worth it, especially since it's a business in our local area. I would certainly come here again when the menu changes!

Name: City Social
Review_Text:
The discreet entrance at ground level of Building 42 needs improvement. It is somewhat confusing and dark, unbecoming of a Michelin-starred establishment. However, once you arrive on the 24th floor via the speedy dedicated elevator, the stunning views of Greater London make a strong first impression. The overall look is impacted by its dark interior, but the decor is elegant and focused on comfortable-looking circular booths with views of the impressive Gherkin building (photos included).

- **Prices**: Despite the location, Michelin status, and quality, the prices are extremely reasonable.
- **Food**: The menu is not very diverse, but it offers good starter options. Bread with caramelized onion butter was a nice addition, but the cocktails were average, with the "Pear-a-dise" being my favorite. The shrimp ravioli and the seabass were my choices. However, the servings are small and the taste average. The food presentation was fine, but not outstanding. There is nothing in the plates we order that needs to be mentioned as remarkable. Again, the food is not bad, but average.
- **Service**: The service was also average, neither excellent nor professionally trained. The staff did their best to make our dinner special, but they seemed to lack knowledge about the menu. For a Michelin restaurant, you expect a more proficient staff. In comparison, in any other restaurant, their level of service would be acceptable.
- **Ambiance**: Definitely not ideal for a romantic dinner. The bar, located at the entrance of the restaurant, has loud music and lots of people chattering, which echoes throughout the dining room. It was quite a noisy meal.

**In Summary**: The restaurant is average but nice. I would not return, but I recommend this place for the views. It is definitely not deserving of a Michelin star based on the food and service, which were good but lacked Michelin quality.

Name: City Social
Review_Text: You have to go up an elevator to get to the floor that the restaurant is on. The restaurant is upscale and classy. Great views of London. The white wine we got was also very good here. Food was not so good - we all had gotten steak and they were completely cooked wrong and 2 of them were almost raw. We sent them back and most of them didn't get fixed to how we wanted them. Service was okay staff stuck up. 4 stars because of the view otherwise would be 3 stars.

Name: City Social
Review_Text: Million dollar view, probably the worst Michelin star restaurant I've tasted so far. I was wondering why it was so easy to get a table and by 7pm on Friday now the restaurant was not full, the menu explained it all. The presentation was ok, but the taste from appetizers to main course was not impressive at all.

Name: City Social
Review_Text: The service was top notch. The food was amazing. And the view was incredible. Everything completely exceeded my expectation.

Name: City Social
Review_Text: The place was difficult to find. The view was amazing even on a foggy day. Wine selection was good. My husband and I ordered lobster ravioli. He was happy with his I thought mine tasted weird and he confirmed it. I become unwell shortly after. Truly a letdown as the place came well recommended from our concierge.

Name: City Social
Review_Text:
Without exaggeration, this place served me the best lobster linguine I have ever tasted. The food is delicious - from starters to desert I had been blown away by the flavours, with some unique exotic twists.

Additionally, the views are spectacular, with broad windows overlooking the city. Truly a romantic scene when you come in the evening.

Nothing to fault about the place. The staff are wonderful and I'll be sure to make another booking soon.

Name: City Social
Review_Text: Went here for dinner and it was amazing! The view was beautiful as well as the food. They got some pretty good gluten free bread. Service is great too. There's also a stool for your bag next to the table.

Name: City Social
Review_Text: I came here for dinner with work friends and we had a great time - talk about a view from your seat at the restaurant - and the food was very good and the service was excellent. We had a variety of appetizers, and it is hard to say what was better the steak or the lobster ravioli: I'd also recommend having the bartender shake you up a vodka martini. If you walk out of here hungry, something is wrong!

Name: City Social
Review_Text:
Come for the views, not the flavor.

Mediocre service and flashy food that lacked inspiration; not the dining experience we expected from a Michelin star.

As you approach City Social, you're greeted with a metal detector and a coat check and then you head up the lift for what we hope would be a memorable London dining experience.

We were early, so we were sat in front of the window at the bar area. The views are truly spectacular and definitely the highlight of the evening.

After sometime, we were greeted by a server to take our drink order. We ordered two specialty cocktails and it was quite obvious the server knew very little about the menu.

The drinks were fantastic. City Social's best people seem to be behind the bar. We also had a great experience with the sommelier that was as fun as they were knowledgable.

We sat for an extended period of time before someone finally came over and took our order.

We ordered the scallop, the prawn/lobster ravioli, and the lobster tail salad.

The appetizers looked nice, but the flavors fell flat.

The prawn/lobster ravioli was my personal favorite, but even that was underwhelming. When we come to restaurants like these we hope to taste something new, but the appetizers were just not that interesting.

The main courses were more of the same. The duck was good, but pretty standard. Nothing to write home about.

Dessert was good. I would actually say the drinks and dessert were the only shining moments of the evening. If I were to come back to City Social, it would likely be for drinks and a dessert and to enjoy the views.

That being said, if you're coming for an inspiring Michelin star meal, I would look elsewhere.

Name: City Social
Review_Text:
I was invited to this restaurant for an exclusive networking event. It was a 5 course meal that did not disappoint! Everything was delicious. It is honestly the most beautiful meal I've ever had. Every dish was explained and there was plenty of wine to go around as well as cocktails on demand. I wish I had taken pictures of every dish, but I was too distracted being immersed in the experiences.

The company putting on the event hired the Chef's table which has a beautiful view of St. Paul's cathedral and central London; as well as a window into the restaurant's kitchen where you can see the food being prepared. The room was just the right size. Even though there were about 14 of us, it felt intimate and everyone could talk with each other around the table. I was surprised as usually round tables of 10 are very awkward yet this one, which was for a bigger party felt cozy.

I definitely recommend it.

Name: City Social
Review_Text:
We were excited to celebrate my wife's birthday at City Social which is decorated with one Michelin star. The view at the restaurant is impeccable! It's located in the heart of London with lots of high rise buildings. We were able to see the Shard and the Gherkin! We arrived early around 5 pm, so we were guided to their bar area for a few drinks. The cocktail, wine, and spirits selections were wonderful. My cocktail Honey Moon was great! They even have non alcoholic cocktail option that was good as well. It was a beautiful restaurant surrounded by all the city lights.
When the dinner room is open, we were invited to the dinner table. Their sourdough bread with onion and chive butter was great! Very delicious. We started with their beef tartare and scallops. The beef tartare was different than the typical beef tartare. The beef was in bigger chunks and the sauce was more vinegar based. I felt the flavor was simple, almost too simple that I wasn't impressed. The scallops starter was wonderful! Layers of flavors and beautifully plated food. It was the highlight of the evening. My main entree was the sea bass with calm chowder based sauce. Beautiful plate, but the overall taste was too salty for me. The portion was solid, but I wasn't impressed by the flavors. It wasn't bad, but I was certainly expecting more from a one star Michelin restaurant. The rib eye steak wasn't impressive neither. We definitely had much better rib eye from a regular restaurant before. Overall, we enjoyed the opportunity to celebrate the birthday dinner at a beautiful restaurant; however, I was disappointed by the food. I was hoping to be blown away by their award winning flavors.

Name: City Social
Review_Text: First experience at a Michelin restaurant, it did not disappoint. Was very luckily to get a reservation on short notice. Everything from drinks, food, dessert and service was beyond anything I've ever had. The view was pretty nice as well. Will definitely try and visit whenever in London.

Name: City Social
Review_Text: Amazing food and incredible views - plus the service wasn't to be matched. The staff was courteous and friendly, and even took us on a tour to see multiple views and a peek in the kitchen. Overall a great experience!

Name: City Social
Review_Text: Amazing dinner with views!!!! Probably my favorite in London so far. We went for my birthday and I would not have wanted it any other way! The scallops, sea bass, and rest all were amazing. Get the apple dessert. It was phenomenal and the perfect way to end our meal.

Name: Dining Room at The Goring
Review_Text: Wonderful afternoon tea on the Veranda. Beautiful space, polite and pleasant service..overall experience was wonderful!

Name: Dining Room at The Goring
Review_Text:
Everything perfect. Service, food and ambient.
Went for the Beef Wellington and it was great.
Definitely a must comeback.

Name: Dining Room at The Goring
Review_Text:
I'm not sure what to say about The Dining Room at The Goring, but I'll give it a try since I'm writing this review.

Incredible service. They had people for everything. They were on top of everything. There wasn't a moment when I was wanting for anything. Probably the best service I've ever had at any restaurant, with a caveat... The sommelier was shockingly unprepared. My girlfriend asked the somm what he would suggest for her main. He picked up the wine book, made a "hmm" noise like he was thinking, and then would make half-hearted suggestions. "Sauvignon Blanc usually goes well with seafood so maybe one of those?" And then would point at a list of Sauv Blancs. I was just surprised that a somm at a restaurant such as this wouldn't have been more prepared with a solid answer. Anyhow.

The food was very good. Not great... But very good. My bisque was amazing. But nothing else was overly rememberable? I'm struggling to recall what I even had. Again - this is my complaint with restaurants of this caliber. So much attention is focused on the presentation and service and not a lot of energy goes into creating food that blows your hair back. But with that - one thing that impressed me was the temperature of the food we received. Everything was just hot enough without being too warm. Love that.

Fanciest restaurant I've ever been to, and probably the most expensive. Not sure it was worth the money, but I enjoyed the experience and have no real regrets.

Name: Dining Room at The Goring
Review_Text: Had afternoon tea here and it was amazing! The dining room is decorated and traditional British style, with lovely large windows to let in the light. The afternoon tea comes with many selections of tea to choose from, pastries, the most delicious scones and clotted cream I've ever had, and delectable finger sandwiches. The staff is attentive and hospitable. I was researching which afternoon tea to choose I'm so glad I chose this one!

Name: Dining Room at The Goring
Review_Text: The server was a total snob. I was disappointed. I've been to better hotels and this guy thought he was too cool for school. I give it a 3/12/ stars. I would not go back.

Name: Galvin La Chapelle
Review_Text:
At Galvin La Chapelle I experienced the worst service of my life. After being seated, a waiter did not come to our table for 50 minutes. We ordered the 7 course tasting menu and didn't receive the 3rd course until after 2 hours of being seated. The entire meal we were neglected by the waitstaff, which included a buffoon of a sommelier who spent more time coughing all over our table than he did describing the wines. When he finally made a wine recommendation, the wine that showed up was sickeningly sweet and tasted nothing like his description.

The 3 dishes that we did eat were mediocre at best, and far below the "Michelin" caliber we expected. I will never come back here and advise you to spend your evenings and money elsewhere. A true embarrassment to fine dining.

Name: Galvin La Chapelle
Review_Text:
what's not to like about this establishment? Certainly delivers on its 1 M star.

We intended to do the tasting menu, but then decided against it as there were several shellfish items that I couldn't have - and I didn't want the veg substitutes. Besides, the a la carte menu had several of the items we wanted to try anyways - so we decided to go with that option - and get 6 items that we could share.

Drinks were excellent! The food even better. Beautifully laid out, and delightful to taste. The only gripe would have, if you could call it that, is that the steak dish just had a bit too much going on on the plate. While the steak was amazing, and paired well with the foie gras, there were just too many additional flavors of the sauce (loved it!) and the individual vegetables. The additional, small beef tip piece completely stumped me - though I enjoyed that as well.

Service was impeccable - attentive, but not overbearing, nor intrusive. Couldn't fault them on this front.

Certainly well worth the visit.

Name: Galvin La Chapelle
Review_Text: We dined here for a client meeting & it was nice. The ambiance of the restaurant is great. It appears to be inside an old building & is a beautiful building. The entrance is really welcoming with lots of flowers. Service was very attentive & great. The food was smaller portion sizes but definitely still enough. I enjoyed it & would be back.

Name: Galvin La Chapelle
Review_Text: absolutely loved this place. incredible service and the best food i've ever had. I will definitely be back.

Name: Galvin La Chapelle
Review_Text: Ordered the dinner 7 course tasting menu for two. The interior and service are very impressive. All of the dishes, however, were too sweet for my liking. I would prefer more savory than sweet. The dry aged beef was too tough for chewing also. For a Michelin star, I expected a bit more. Dessert and cocktails were amazing though. 3 1/2 stars in my book.

Name: Harwood Arms
Review_Text: Amazingly surprised. If there is such an expression. This is a Michelin restaurant. And well worth it. Entrees and main dish are highly original in taste and presentation.

Name: Harwood Arms
Review_Text: Amazing game offerings in a tasteful and adventurous setting. Excellent service staff. Don't miss this gem!

Name: Harwood Arms
Review_Text:
We really loved The Harwood Arms. It is such a pleasure to have exceptional food in a casual, relaxed setting. The dining room is rustic and cozy. And even though The Harwood Arms is a pub, the service is top notch.

The food is classic British cooking with a focus on game and wild meat. My favorite dish was the venison scotch egg with Oxford sauce. It was beautiful with a runny golden yolk. My only complaint is that it came out with instead of ahead of my starter as requested.

The thyme flavored sauce on the rabbit lasagne was phenomenal. The Berkshire Fallow Deer was perfectly cooked and served with mushrooms and onions. They had dessert special, a date custard tart, that we were lucky to get.

I also enjoyed their gin list and tried three different English gins, each one delicious.

I highly recommend it.

Name: Harwood Arms
Review_Text: We visited on Sunday for roast dinner - Oh my! Great location in quiet neighborhood. Old corner bar full of charm and friendly staff. We arrived without reservations and between meal rushes and after a drink at the bar we were seated. The Sunday roast is an event, served for two with plenty of everything. See picture. Great tasting food, gravy and veggies - haven't head a better Sunday roast. We were never rushed and felt like we were eating at a friend's home. Great meal and experience

Name: Harwood Arms
Review_Text: Great food and a great environment. We were lucky to get a table and it was an amazing experience. Highly recommend!

Name: Harwood Arms
Review_Text:
Dinner at Harwood Arms was absolutely exquisite from beginning to end. It's the only Michelin-starred pub in London, and although it's definitely a posh experience dining here, it doesn't feel stuffy or pretentious. It still has a level of comfort.

The staff was attentive and patient. One member of our group got an important phone call from her son in the United States and had to step out to talk to him for a few minutes, and they gave us some space and never made us feel like we were wasting their time as they waited to take our orders.

The food is absolutely fantastic. From the wonderful brown bread and perfectly creamy butter, to every other bite of food that graced our table.

The onion tart was exceptional, the tomato was so perfectly balanced with the most adorable little croutons for texture, all of our main courses and especially the best potatoes ever, which were twice cooked, boiled and then fried in GARLIC BUTTER! They were so crispy and delicious. I couldn't get over it. Dessert too absolutely hit the mark.

This meal was another one of those totally memorable, totally must bookmark this spot and return on any future visit to London because it was truly that good. It is worth going out of your way to eat here, trust me.

Name: Harwood Arms
Review_Text: One of the best restaurants I went to while in London. There was 4 of us we all tried each other's food and I can tell you every single thing was amazing. It wasn't too rich or filling but just really good food. I loved the modern look of a pub style restaurant too. I definitely would recommend this place to anyone

Name: Harwood Arms
Review_Text: Great atmosphere, fish and chips was fantastic . Bar was an upbeat mix of all ages. Weight staff was very professional and friendly

Name: Harwood Arms
Review_Text: Service was great! Seated promptly. Food is cooked above restaurant and lowered in these dumb waiters. So cool! The venison was perfect. Didn't taste gamey at all! I didn't like the taste of a ground meat in my dish but it was okay. The beef short Rib was tender. Really loved the onion tart and Scotch egg. It was a great experience.

Name: Harwood Arms
Review_Text: I came here for dinner and absolutely loved it! The staff knew we were celebrating, so they gave us a card and an additional dessert. Those were very nice touches. It's nice that it's a prix fixe menu, so we were able to try every course. For my drink, I had the Kir Britannia, which was very good. For my starter, I had the seasonal vegetables, which came with smoked trout. It was absolutely beautiful to look at, and it was amazing! For my main, I had the fallow deer, which was also great! Our server gave us smashed potatoes with it, and they complemented each other nicely. For my dessert, I had the lemon thyme panna cotta, and it was so refreshing! We also had the apricot ice cream, and it was full of apricot flavor! Everything was outstanding, and I really recommend trying it out! The workers are really great, too!

Name: Harwood Arms
Review_Text:
We came for a late lunch with an absolute empty stomach but we were sooooo full we can barely fit in the dessert.

£65 per person for a three course menu but a supplemental £7.50 for the sirloin. There's a special steak for a supplemental £12.50 but we thought might try their standard first.

Alcohol is very high quality- I had the white wine (forgot which one but I always op for the second cheapest) and it was very very luxurious. My friend had the beer with champagne and it was very interesting in the best way.

We chose the pate and onion tart for our starter. Very tasty - perhaps we are hungry - and we literally inhaled it.

The deer - loved it as I'm a big fan of gamy stuff. It's on the salty side though so pair it with a potato is perfect. It was very yummy.

Sirloin was very nice actually. I was so skeptical because steaks are very tricky but they did it beautifully.

All the sides are great especially the giant crispy Yorkshire pudding but the only thing is they only gave us two strips of carrot :(

By the time it's dessert, we are already so full that we debate about packing it to go. This says a lot because we usually try to finish our food. But god that was good. It was so good that even with a max out stomach, I still found it tasty. And I'm not a dessert person.

The bill comes to around £180 with 3 drinks in total. Not cheap but the quality was definitely there. Never have I ever had such a posh pub meal before. Haha

Name: Harwood Arms
Review_Text:
Food 6/10
Great meal, but it was just not the type of food I enjoy the most. Scottish venison eggs and onion tart were the highlights of my meal. It was overall quite a rich and hearty meal, with no breaks, as we started with the rich scotch eggs, had some complimentary rye bread with whipped butter (delicious and warm), and ended with deer, mushrooms, in a creamy and heavy sauce. My stomach was not at its best when we ended this meal, but I did enjoy getting a chance to try the flavors.

Atmosphere 7/10
Very much a gastropub vibe. Dark wooden interior with fur decor (no clue if it's real or not). We were seated in a snug corner, vibes.

Service 5/10
Even though we were seated at 8:30, we didn't get to our main until 10pm, so it was quite a delayed meal. Wish it was faster, they were not as attentive as I had hoped.

Name: Harwood Arms
Review_Text:
Hardwood Arms is a great value. The wife and I made a visit in August 2023
Nice selection of house cocktails, we each opted for a fancy gin and tonic
Also have an extensive wine list from around the world, we opted for a cote de Rhône
Dinner was a fixed priced at 65 pounds
We each had the onion tart for starters
For dinner the Ms. Selected the cod and I had the short rib
For dessert the wife had the cheese plate and i had the evening special which was apricot ice cream with a bunch of different crisps.
Overall the food was very well done, creative and the evening was memorable. Overall total was 265 pounds

If you are in London, check them out. You will not be disappointed.

J

Name: Harwood Arms
Review_Text:
Very tight menu but something for everyone in our party of 6. All options were amazing. Service amazing. Wine by the bottle prices were a bit high, although the by the glass options were wonderful and well priced. Between all of us we tried and ordered 90% of the menu - thumbs up all around.

Great quiet location within a leisurely walking distance from Earls Court station. Very accommodating to one individual in our group who had a food sensitivity. Service was impeccable.

Name: Harwood Arms
Review_Text:
We were excited to try The Harwood Arms to scratch our "traditional English pub meal" itch. We were pleased with the experience, but wish that a few things would have been better.

The place is tucked away in a quiet neighborhood and the decor is so charming--like an elevated pub-centric vibe. The sloe gin spritz was one of the best cocktails that one of us has ever had (she ordered two), and we appreciated that the goblet came with a straw that was the right size for the glass. It's a three course prix fixe menu, but we also started with the venison Scotch egg because 1) we love Scotch eggs and 2) we're in England. Needless to say, it was flawless. The yolk was perfectly runny, the meat was moist, the crumb was crisp. 10/10! Our daughter liked it so much that she had almost half of it.

We chose the warm pumpkin tart and spring vegetable salad for our starters course. The flavor of the pumpkin and goat cheese was a match made in heaven, but the filling had gone mealy, so the whole texture was off. The salad course was beautifully presented, but it was more like a Russian kind of salad with the focus being on the potatoes and sour cream. The components were individually arranged, so you really had to mix everything up to fully appreciate the dish. Our entrees were the best part of the meal (after the Scotch egg). We got the Cornish Hake and the short rib. BRAVO. Both dishes were flawless. The short rib was beyond tender and we loved that it was wrapped in the greens--the confit made you want to lick the plate. The fish was also incredible with a buttery flakiness that contrasted nicely with some of the firmer beans; the artichokes were a welcome addition.

Dessert wasn't the best. The blood orange trifle was definitely something special that you don't see everyday but some of the buttermilk components threw us off. We also had the apricot special that sounded right up our alley, but again, it seemed unnecessarily ambitions. The pastry layers were more like crackers gone wrong, and wish that there had been something else tying in all the other delicious elements together; still, we appreciated the ice cream and fresh fruit and creams.

Service oscillated from extremely warm to haughty brusque. They definitely seemed more harried as the place filled up, but we wouldn't necessarily say it was good or bad--more like, just managing to make the whole thing work. That said, we would highly recommend The Harwood Arms to others as it's definitely making pub food more inventive and exciting.

Name: Harwood Arms
Review_Text: We visited the Harwood Arms a few years ago and at this is no different. Still the cozy but friendly atmosphere with good food.

Name: Harwood Arms
Review_Text:
Outstanding. My girlfriend & I sought out restaurants with a Michelin star for our vacation, and Harwood Arms was one of the ones we selected. Of all the restaurants we chose for a vacation, Harwood Arms rose to the very top.

- The decor.
- The service.
- The food.
- The presentation.
- The vibe.
- The price.

Everything was great. I would go back to the Harwood Arms without question. I was so enamored with my meal that I forgot to take any photos whatsoever, ergo my pictureless review.

Just take my word for it. Go to the Harwood Arms and enjoy your experience.

Name: Harwood Arms
Review_Text: Fantastic 3 course meal. Some dishes we had: Smoked Eel Soup, Pumpkin Tart, Short Rib, Deer, Pineapple Upside Down Cake and Custard Flan

Name: HIDE
Review_Text:
HIDE The most beautiful brunch||" Overall, the taste is good, but not amazing. The presentation is indeed very delicate, and the environment is very good.
The two of us ordered almost all the popular dishes in the store. The waiter advised us that we ordered too much, but in fact, the portion was not large and it was okay.

French toast with blueberry compote & crème crue It looks ordinary but I was shocked when I took the first bite. It has a strong milky flavor but is not greasy at all. It was a dish that was eaten in a flash. It was so delicious that I wanted to add an order immediately. I told my friend that I would eat two servings each next time.

Acai bowl with berries Delicious yogurt bowl, beautiful presentation, a must-order dish.
‍Black truffled scrambled eggs on toast The most anticipated black truffle scrambled eggs, the taste is actually a bit bland, and the edges of the toast are a bit hard.
Croque Monsieur This one has a stronger flavor, but it's also a bit hard, so hard to cut hahaha.

Ordinary mango, pickled with a little floral fragrance, but I've forgotten what it tastes like now.
Smoothie, my friend said it's also delicious, you can't go wrong with any of it.

Make an appointment, brunch is before 10:30, and then it's lunch. Opposite is Green Park, you can go for a walk after dinner to digest the food, it's really comfortable.

Name: HIDE
Review_Text: I've eaten at Hide three times--once for lunch and twice for dinner. I highly recommend it for lunch rather than dinner. The lunch menu was innovative, and the food presentation was exceptional. In contrast, my dinner experiences were unsatisfying and disappointing.

Name: HIDE
Review_Text: I'll miss the Hide Bar but especially Amber. Last evening was her last after many years. I have a very special memory there and Amber was always the greatest.

Name: HIDE
Review_Text: We made a reservation for breakfast as we were headed back to the states later in the afternoon. Exceptional from start to finish. Such a spectacularly beautiful space, a sunny seat by the window perfect for people watching. The staircase is a piece of art. Their gourmet coffee selections were the perfect beginning. The honey mango was the best I've had in my life and melted in my mouth. The seasonal fruit was also delicious with a lemon verbena pour over. My husband thoroughly enjoyed the French toast with blueberry compote and a side of black pudding and I loved my Eggs Florentine with a lovely bright hollandaise and perfect super yellow runny yolk. I look forward to trying lunch and/or dinner when we are back in June.

Name: HIDE
Review_Text: I tried the tasting menu. The presentation and wine selections were absolutely stunning. But I feel like the presentation overpowers the food overall. The food was okay and not amazing as I thought it would be.

Name: HIDE
Review_Text:
Had an absolutely fabulous meal at Hide, my best during this trip to London. To begin with, Hide has a lovely bar in the basement floor. Really nice ambiance and great selection of top shelf liquor. Lively, but not overly crowded.
We had dinner in the room on the top floor. Tables well spaced and a nice view of Piccadilly.
Appetizers were all excellent but mine, the soft shell crab with a Thai green chile sauce was spectacular. The crab was crispy but not dry and the sauce had just the right amount of heat. The mains were also excellent. The halibut perfectly cooked with a nice sauce. I hit the jackpot with the loin rib of venison that was amazing. Cooked to the perfect temperature, with a killer juniper berry sauce.
We just had one dessert, the quince tart, with an amazing crust and tasty small scoop of ice cream, which was the perfect accompaniment.
Service was top notch and the wine list one of the best in London. Great range of selections, many of which are well aged. Sommelier was very, very knowledgeable and happy to assist.
Just a great dining experience that I highly recommend.

Name: HIDE
Review_Text: Very cool restaurant with beautiful interiors and the food to go along with it. We went for brunch and ordered a couple of items below in the photos. And everything was excellent. We had the truffle eggs and toast which was good and also had the Croque Monsieur and added truffles. If I got the Croque Monsieur next time I don't think I would add the truffles though. It would be excellent without. I also had 2 cappuccino's one with the normal coffee and the other with a specialty coffee from Colombia and both were fantastic. The one from Colombia was a little stronger. Overall I would go back in a heartbeat to try more items. And try one of the other floors.

Name: HIDE
Review_Text: Another fantastic meal here. This visit, the courses were timed perfectly without any long gaps in service. The wine pairings were excellent and nicely complemented the delicious food. I highly recommend Hide!

Name: HIDE
Review_Text: Hide is on the edge of Green Park. It is a beautiful and novel setting with lots of wood. The lower bar is charming, somewhat chalet themed. The wine cellar down there is amazing and you can ask for a tour with the sommelier. We ate a variety of dishes, fish mostly which was served beautifully. It merits is Michelin Star.

Name: HIDE
Review_Text: Well. The place is beautiful. The food was spectacular. The charcuterie of meats was served on a slab of slate with thin cuts of cured lamb, duck, beef and pork. The mackerel tartare with a lovely gratinee that melted into a lovely sauce came on a smoking icy display of seaweed. Well done on the drama. The others that had the pasta and the scallop appetizers were wowed. Our mains: The John Dory was was wrapped in a thin zucchini flower. So delicate and beautiful with the pale orange and green veins enveloping a perfectly cooked piece of fish. The sauces complimented nicely too. The duck was delicious and the lamb amazing. Reports at the table gave the octopus two thumbs up. Everything was prepared to perfection. The desserts--omg! The banana milkshake with the crisp ice cream bites! The best best best was the warm acorn cake with a warm salted caramel sauce doused in a liqueur of your choice--we went with a delicious smoky mezcal. Very well done!! Now comes the "but." The service. It felt like a soft opening. No one but the female sommelier could get their act together. We sat 45 min before a waiter approached to take an appetizer order. Uh . . . How about cocktails???? We gently asked for a cocktail menu and wine list. They brought an I pad --one I pad for a table of 5. Well that took a while. We ordered some apps, enjoyed the delicious bread basket and olives and settled in. There was a big gap before dinner came, but we were ok. It's just that we had two servers serving us, so we did not know whom we asked for what. The som was professional, so helpful and lovely. She served red and white, apologized for the wrong glasses (really? Michelin star reviewer, did you not order wine? I felt her pain) and tracked down a cocktail that was ordered 30 minutes before (and brought two). The waiters dress like busboys and the busser/water refiller was in a suit (and super wonderful). A bit confusing at the start. So--go for the food and as my son said to me, "chill" and enjoy. But this NYer says someone called in sick. Also--no one came to the table to ask if things were good/cooked properly etc.

Name: HIDE
Review_Text: We had an amazing dinner at the Hide restaurant today. From the moment we walked in, we were blown away by the elegant uniqueness of the dining room. We were given a table in the upper room, so we got to use the beautiful wooden staircase. We started with a flat bread appetizer (amazing!), then I opted for deconstructed vegetable lasagna (to die for!) and my husband ordered their lamb dish (he loved it!). Our side dishes were broccoli with vinaigrette and baby potatoes- both side dishes were full of unique flavors and were very tasty. Our dessert was the blueberry cobbler with amazing homemade ice cream. The dessert was just as divine and the cherry flavored black tea was absolutely amazing. We were literally blown away by how amazing the Hide restaurant was.

Name: HIDE
Review_Text: Food was good but not amazingly good as I would've expected from a starred place. I had the duck which was good, and the signature nest egg, which was too umami for me. The service was also slightly disorganized for such an establishment.

Name: HIDE
Review_Text: As reassuringly expensive ( think £300/head for five course tasting menu+ matched flight of wines) as you would want from a fashionable restaurant in Mayfair. The food varies from excellent to really very good. Service is friendly but precise- in particular I would commend the sommelier. She took care to answer all of our questions ( quite apart from doing a very good job). Design is also a big feature, from the architect Alex Haw's hallmark sweeping staircase, to the artful partial views into the kitchens. One to go to with someone you really like, particularly if someone else is paying.

Name: HIDE
Review_Text: Great staff and service. Beautiful dining room and artfully plated dishes. The food was good, but sadly didn't match the level of it's surroundings. The flavors were boring. Had the soft shelled crab, lamb and elderflower baba. The crab needed more depth, the lamb was well made but tasted like lamb from any mediterranean restaurant and the flavors and texture of the baba didn't really mesh.

Name: HIDE
Review_Text:
This place was my favorite meal my entire trip through 4 European countries! And kind you I ate at multiple Michelins/top 50 restaurants. First of all, the restaurant is gorgeous. We sat on the second floor and got to walk up that gorgeous spiral staircase. We sat right next to the floor to ceiling windows with a few of the park across the street.

For the lunch menu, they start you off with a bread basket, charcuterie style meat beautiful plated on bones, and a couple other treats. I chose the trout tartare as my starter, pork for entree, and custard tart for dessert. My goodness everything was a hit, seriously. There wasn't anything I didn't enjoy. The custard tart reminded me of nata and I thought it was so smart to pair it with the cider! You usually sprinkle a little cinnamon on nata so I feel like the cider played to that concept. Sooo delish!

Service was great and food was paced well! The lunch menu is a great deal for those looking for a solid meal without breaking the bank too much.

Name: HIDE
Review_Text:
Went to Above at Hide for their lunch, and absolutely loved the experience. Walking in, you can understand right away why this place got michelin star. Greeted by the gorgeous entrance is awe-striking oak staircase that I only might have seen in some pretty magazine. The top floor is light-wooded with delicate and elaborate decorations. You can tell even from the table, cutlery holders and plates that every single element has been so thoughtfully placed in such beautiful way such that we can enjoy every moment there.
Every staff were extremely kind to me - as soon as I was seated, a staff came to let me know if I need to charge my phone, there's a portable charger placed in the drawer of the table, and showed me the options for my menu. Another staff came with a drink cart to offer me drinks, and soon someone else came bringing out a little stool to place my bag.

I got their 5 course set lunch since I wasn't too hungry. Throughout my meal, I was so happy, every bite made me smile. With a serene view outside facing the Green park, immaculately created dishes with perfectly balanced flavours, not only my mouth but my eyes were also in awe and happiness.

Would recommend to anyone coming to London and would definitely come back when I'm back in London!

Name: HIDE
Review_Text:
Ok this place is def fancy so for a nice fancy breakfast next to the park amongst fancy people it's a good option.

You're going to see your average bored wealthy types who prob didn't earn their money but think they are important.

The service is very good. The food is beautiful....but the taste of things didn't quite match.

The croissant was amazing! Like shattering glass on the outside and fluffy and chewy inside. They bring you this lemon butter and different jams that were great.

Teas and coffees amazing!

The Avocado toast was meh. Your average hipster coffee shop could crush it.

The fruit salad was depressing the fruits were all flavorless.

God I sound like such a whiny beeyotch.

The place is beautiful, the crowd there made me feel like a poor person, the pastries seem the way to go for sure and I think I might go again for fun.

Name: HIDE
Review_Text:
This was it. The final food I would be purchasing in London during my trip. One Michelin Star, customizable tasting menu, great buzz, sounded like a winner. So we get here super early, actually, and took about 60 seconds to find the front door, because it was hidden, but they have a bar downstairs, called Below Hide, which had some nice mocktails, so we killed some time there.

At the time of our reservation, we were lead up two flights of their absolutely gorgeous stairs to our section, Above at Hide. We got seated and started carefully making our decisions. Because this was another wonderful London restaurant where, for the majority of the courses, we got a choice of which dish we wanted. Love the options.

There were five- and seven- course options. We chose the five. The seven seemed to be a cheese plate and another dessert, which we would have loved to have, but I don't know, guess we weren't feeling it that night.

The whole experience started with Gem, Bread & broth, and Flesh & bone. Three little bites. Gem was a leaf of lettuce, with the purpose of being dipped in some grain or nuts or something, I can't remember, and to be used as a chip to that dip. It was fun. The bread was really good. Five very distinct varieties of bread in a basket, with a fine dollop of butter on a plate. Always love bread.

And the Flesh & bone was the most striking presentation. Fancy pork/beef, charcuterie style, wrapped around the ends of feathers, and what looked like a bone. Quick bite, one and done. Delicious, fun. A great start.

Another small dish was the Turnip with pine nuts, honey & eucalyptus. Finely cut up strips of turnip soaking in a honey eucalyptus broth. Very clean tasting, like a palate cleanser.

The last little small bite that we both had the same thing, before the dishes started differing was the Nest egg. This was a slowly, barely cooked egg mixed with super delicious mushrooms, served in a brown egg that had it's top cut off. Needless to say, very fun, very delicious. I wasn't to break the egg to lick the inside of the shell, because I wanted more.

Then, our tasting menu truly began. And unfortunately, their menu has already changed, so I have no idea what I ate. I say unfortunate, but I actually love that their menu is super seasonal, and probably changes frequently.

But I do know that I had an excellent monkfish in a dashi broth, a nice lobster in a cream sauce, a perfectly cooked dusk with some black currents, and another sweetbread. There were also a couple of nice desserts, a fresh fruit one with some homemade ice cream, and there was a very pretty pasty, made to look like a gemstone. Great fun.

Our last, shared small bites, were the Chestnut & malt pillows and the Acorns. Nut-filled, chewy nougat. And a crispy pillow full of dessert stuff I don't remember what is was, but it was fun, it was light, and it was a good way to wind down from the meal.

We paid the bill, got our cake-home baggy full of delicious cookies, and left.

Overall, this was a fun journey. I don't know how long this place has had the One Star, but they definitely seem like they're pushing for that second Star. Who knows. But yes, five stars. Come here.

Name: HIDE
Review_Text:
I really wanted to like this place. The servers and sommeliers were superb. The appetizers and nest egg were creative and delicious but I felt the main entrees felt too busy, with clashing tastes.

They started off with bread ( I loved the black pudding) , lettuce and beet juice that all tasted great. The turnip served in the broth was excellent despite served cold.

However, the main dishes were quite the opposite to the appetizers and desserts in that they were unbalanced. the Chilean sea bass with the pear did not pair well in fact did not go well together at all and the scallops was just ok. My venison was tough and the flatbread was soggy and the wagyu was just ok. We did the 5 course menu but we were so full we skipped the optional cheese menu.

As for desserts the tarte tartin is very sweet but goes pairs well with the ice cream which balances it out. The rhubarb tartlet was ok but I found the pastry portion too delicate. The tarte tartin won for me.

Tbh I wish the nest egg could be it's own a la carte bc I find it unique and it sucked we had to do the tasting in order to get the nest egg.

The tasting menu and the regular a la carte menu are quite different.

Name: HIDE
Review_Text: This one-star Michelin star restaurant is a find. Teh mussel custard, chicken (yes chicken) and papillete vegetarian dishes were all delicious. Service was helpful and efficient. The total spend with tip was 163 pounds for two which did not include alcohol, but expresso and sparkling water. Bread was 9 pounds. For the money, the quality was high, and meal was more than worth the spend.

Name: Jamavar
Review_Text:
2/5 Food
1/5 Service
5/5 Interior
5/5 Bathroom

I recently came here for dinner and was very disappointed. To me, the most important aspect of any restaurant, Michelin star on not, is the food. The food here was palatable, edible, but not one dish stood out and the flavors were nothing special.

The service was abysmal. Highlights included:
- Being offered only the a la carte menu and having to request the tasting menu
- Getting the wine pairing and then each wine being put on the table with descriptors like, "this is a sparkling wine." There was a som on the premises, but he did not come to our table
- Sticky stems on the cocktail glasses
- Plates sitting untouched after a course for 10 minutes, and then a server coming to the table and saying, "ya done?" before taking the plates

I'm unsure if this was just an off night for this restaurant, but I wouldn't return, and I would advise people against coming here. The experience was a waste of time and money.

Name: Jamavar
Review_Text:
One of the best Indian meals of my life. The Dehli butter chicken was amazing, the Saag Paneer was transcendent and alive with fresh spinach flavor, and the tandoori prawns were beyond fresh, with a perfect seasoning and just a kiss of char from the Tandoor.
I would not order the lobster or the kid mains again, but that's just my taste. I will absolutely return.

Name: Jamavar
Review_Text: We were travelling to London from NYC and got food poisoning. We called them to cancel our reservation and asked to waive the fee as a courtesy since we were there only for 3-4 days so there was no way for us to reschedule, the lady on the phone said she needs to confirm with the manager but as its health related they should be able to do a courtesy. They charged us anyway and when we disputed with our card, they counter disputed claiming their policy. This is the worst greediest experience I've seen at any restaurant. They are sending me emails, claiming their money with no empathy or understanding of a health situation. We live in NYC and have been to many Michelin star restaurants and never experienced this in London or NYC or anywhere. I have made a note to never go here again, London offers so many excellent Indian restaurants, stay away from this one.

Name: Jamavar
Review_Text:
Food 4.5/5.0
Service 3.5/5.0
Value 3.5/5.0
Decor 3.5/5.0
Overall 4.0/5.0

Great spot just off Berkeley Square. A bit pricey but food was excellent. Would definitely come back.

Name: Jamavar
Review_Text: Incredible food! Delicious drinks! Great service! We are from California - had high expectations of Indian food in London. This place exceeded our expectations in every way.

Name: Jamavar
Review_Text: I been to this Reasturant on new year the food was so good and o had some drinks at downs the bar man Mr Tony he made amazing cocktails I loved there food and especially drinks.

Name: Jamavar
Review_Text: Service was awesome and the meal from start to finish was amazing including the drink & wine. Our top favorites were the milk pistachio cake, the morels dish, truffle kicchadi, and the paneer. Pulao & jamavar dhal were also cooked nicely. Can tell they use good ingredients and I wouldn't hesitate to recommend. The restaurant is more upscale, so dress appropriately.

Name: Jamavar
Review_Text: Top notch Indian food in London that will not disappoint. Service is impeccable. Only thing is the music is a bit dance club like for dinner. Otherwise, will return another time.

Name: Jamavar
Review_Text:
Not sure how they earned and maintain a Michelin star.

We went there with high expectations, and had the tasting menu.

Overall, the first several courses were amazing. They were absolutely perfect - though the lamb chops could have done with a little more spice. The last course of Butter chicken, daal makhani and saag paneer, with an assortment of naans were a bit of a disappointment. They were on the blander side, and the naans were cold and rubbery - not something one would expect in a tasting menu. The desserts were good, but not great. So, food good, but not 1-star worthy.

Presentation - non-existent! At most 2 of the courses were 'pretty', but the rest of them were quite unimpressively laid out - again, not 1-star worthy.

Service - this is where this restaurant completely lost us. We arrived on time, and despite making the reservation months ago, were given a small table right at the back of the restaurant next to the billing station. it was crammed and lacked any privacy. Service was unattentive, and we literally had to keep asking them for it. After the 1st course arrived, we still hadn't gotten our drinks. Upon reminding them of that, the waiter returned to our table and had to retake our drinks order. Ever heard of that in a Michelin starred restaurant??? They had been informed that I was allergic to shellfish - and so brought me a substitute for my 1st course. However, that simple fact was forgotten in the 2nd course serving. Luckily I asked - otherwise, I would have been in serious trouble.

Bottomline is that this is by far the worst service we've ever had a restaurant of this caliber. I wouldn't be surprised if they aren't able to retain it next go round.

Name: Jamavar
Review_Text:
Still scratching our heads as to how this restaurant has a Michelin star. Most of the food was very good, but then there were several things that were lacking - that you never encounter in a restaurant of such rating.

The first thing we noticed as we entered was that all the brown people were seated towards the back of the restaurant...... many of the "brown people" were from the US - today's big spenders, but I figure these guys never got the message.

Service was absolutely lousy. We had to constantly call out to the staff for service. Our drinks required a reminder and arrived after our first course. I'm allergic to shellfish, and one of the courses they apparently forgot that..... a BIG no-no in my books - especially when I am extremely allergic to shellfish.

The first several courses of the tasting menu (we seemed to be the only people there doing the tasting menu) were amazing! However, the courses towards the end were just so-so. The butter chicken was a bit strange, the accompaniments - daal makhani and saag paneer were just about OK. The naans not great - in fact not even good - they were on the harder side and barely warm. The desserts while good, were just OK - and poorly presented. In fact all the dishes were presented rather poorly - with may be 1 of them being photo worthy.

SO, overall, lousy service. Not-so-good presentation of the dishes. Most food items were excellent - though lacking towards the end - so inconsistent quality. Given that ratings are generally based on the tasting menu, I won't be surprised if these guys lose their 1 star rating in the near future.

Name: Jamavar
Review_Text:
We had tickets to a show at the West End so wanted to have a fancy dinner out. We made reservations and as soon as we arrived we were seated. They were attentive throughout dinner and very polite. The restaurant was elegantly decorated, a nice date place.
So to the important part, the food. I ordered the Old Delhi Butter Chicken and my husband ordered the biryani. We also had mixed breads for the table. For drinks, I got the lassi and my husband got the Spring Garden. The presentation was beautiful. The lassi had a small flower floating in it. It cut through the spice nicely. The Spring Garden was a refreshing fruit drink.
I really enjoyed the butter chicken. The sauce was great over rice or on the naan. The biryani came covered by a pastry cap that they cut off revealing a steamy bowl of well seasoned rice and meat. It was all very good but at twice the cost of average Indian food. However, average Indian food is still pretty good at arguably a better value. So ultimately, this is a special occasion place.

Name: Jamavar
Review_Text: We made a reservation for Jamavar months in advance. I asked the dress code and was told casual. When we arrived with our two teenaged boys, we were turned away at the door. The boys had on a button down collared shirt with khaki shorts. Apparently, casual didn't mean shorts no matter how nicely dressed they were. They then charged us $100 the next day for not making our reservation. We not only had to scramble for another dinner, but were charged for breaking our reservation. So disappointing.

Name: Jamavar
Review_Text: Yes it's fine dining and it lives up to to the standard. Great food and ambiance, ok service, CTM was good as was the garlic naan and rich, butter chicken was fine, lamb chops were undercooked and a rip off for the price, would go again minus the chops.

Name: Jamavar
Review_Text:
We came with such high hopes and left hungry and disappointed. If you know what good Indian food is then you should avoid this place. It's too bad that Michelin was duped by the high prices, expensive building, and posh location in downtown London -- the food leaves much to be desired.

The menu is lovely but beware -- the portions are tiny and the flavors aren't fully developed. Appetizers seemed to do better for our group than main dishes -- they were beautifully presented and were widely enjoyed. The curries and main dishes all tasted the same and lacked depth. The naan was ok -- if not slightly over cooked.

If you get off spending 300 pounds on dinner that you could get for 50 from your neighborhood Indian place then please come here. Otherwise, steer clear.

Name: Jamavar
Review_Text: When you walk into the restaurant it feels like a club with the music in the background, not necessarily a fan of loud music when I go out for dinner. But it's cozy restaurant with beautiful decor. The best way to describe the food was homemade taste with elevated style. We had the aloo tiki, shami kabob, vegetable biryani and lamp chop kebabs. It's Indian spicy, which was perfect and the food was delicious. The cocktails were refreshing, we had the royal blush and the ginger mango mule. The waitstaff was great, felt like they were attentive to us and other patrons. We were treated to a small birthday surprise of ras malai at the end. Just a great place for any special occasion or dinner date. Believe me you will not be disappointed. We were visiting from the US and I've only had desi food like this a handful of times in the Bay Area and Vancouver.

Name: Jamavar
Review_Text:
Fine Indian dining in London.. highly recommended.. the apetizers were good, lamb felt a bit like it was pressure cooked and then put in the masala ( I could be wrong) The upstairs seating is much better as when i went downstairs to the restroom felt it was a totally different atmosphere and not the same Jamavar i have been here few times. Prices are good and great place to spend a Friday night in London!
Bill turned out 222 pounds ($275) for 3.

Name: Jamavar
Review_Text:
Amazing Indian food, great service, fantastic drinks!
Probably the best briani I had! Totally recommend.

Name: Kai
Review_Text: The Aromatic Crispy Duck was very dry, a poor choice, especially as the lamb we observed on the adjacent table which was occupied by a famous US tennis professional looked scrumptious. At this level, one would expect every choice to be spectacular.

Name: Kai
Review_Text:
Easily one of my favorite restaurants in London. Conveniently located in Mayfair. This spacious and moody restaurant does evoke the spirit of big Asian cities like Tokyo and Hong Kong. We came with vegans and vegetarians and service was so helpful in having us make an informed decision.

We got wasabi shrimp which is a must get- nothing else like it. Also spicy chicken and the faux Peking duck which is absolutely sublime - I would eat it everyday if I could.

Name: Kai
Review_Text:
Honestly disappointed. The service was a bit weird here. Outwardly friendly but not that helpful.

What I remembered of the food - the wasabi prawn was good but it's not that unique. It tastes like wasabi honey mustard on a shrimp tempura. And the pandan creme brulee had little taste of pandan and was quite liquid, not as set as I would have expected.

Name: Kai
Review_Text: My recent experience was not the first at this beautiful restaurant. I took my daughter to the afternoon tea. We arrived slightly early but we accommodated straight away as the table was already set. As I have a mobility issue, the hostess, very kind and polite found an alternative route which was a nice start. The waiter was very pleasant. However, the limited amount and variety of food was poor. The decor was splendid, we have awaited for the food for quite some time. 5 minutes after tea was served we were told that kitchen is closing, we had hardly a chance to taste anything we are asked what else do we want. We felt really rushed. The creme brulee was too similar with the cake served. In my opinion below average quality for a Mishelin star restaurant. Then waiter said goodbye as he had to leave. During less than 2 hours stay. Disappointing but it can happen. Also rose tea was a tea bag. We could not eat our money cakes, I asked to take them. Our waitress told us we cannot. I asked what do you do with these cakes now, she said we throw they away. I refused for the 1st time in my life to pay the service charge. She repeated it again So you refuse to pay the Service charge, Madam. Hm, I think something is seriously wrong with the Management. Poor experience and poor value for money. There are a number of places we have been and enjoyed more. It would be inappropriate to comment any further.

Name: Kai
Review_Text:
5 stars for the fabulous afternoon tea service!

I did a ton of research on where to go for tea and Kai was an undiscovered gem my husband found for us. The tea is a little less traditional but an awful lot of fun from the moment you sit down to the perfectly set table. The tea is on the bottom floor of this dark and romantically lit restaurant (be warned, if you're there for the gram you may need a little extra light for the perfect shot) and only has a handful of tables so I'd highly recommend reservations. We arrived right when tea started at 3pm and stayed until the end time at 5pm - Kai offers unlimited refills of both the sweets and savories in addition to the tea so two hours was the perfect amount of time. The tea menu is fairly limited and most teas have an upcharge so note that the emphasis here is more on the food and experience than the brew (though it is served on the most perfect china set).

To start you get a sweet little cocktail (non-alcoholic available as well) with fun edible garnishes. Then a pot of conversation tea cookies arrives. Then the main course, a three-level tower of sweet and savory treats along with saucer-sized macarons and small jars of sweet toppings to put on them. Macarons instead of scones was a little upsetting to me and the only misstep as who wants to put clotted cream on a macaron?! We loved almost all of the savory options, the prawn on toast being our favorite and the hot soup being the least compelling. The sweets were a little less up my alley as I'm a chocolate girl but they had a wonderful selection of flavors that fit with the Chinese theme that chocolate doesn't play much of a part in. The biscuit cookie was pretty but stale and bland, the money cake we each had three of it was so good.

My favorite part of the Kai afternoon tea was the fabulous service. We were greeted and seated promptly, given ample refills and we felt completely comfortable despite being the least chicly-dressed people there that afternoon (we had come from a full day of walking in cold weather - everyone else had clearly arrived just for the tea ;p). Highly recommend!

Name: Kai
Review_Text: Very beautiful restaurant interior and polite service. The food was artfully presented. The tongue numbing fish was fantastic. We were a bit disappointed by the chili lobster dish since it felt like for the price we paid, we didn't get much seafood. The pandan crime brûlée was fantastic though--a must order!

Name: Kai
Review_Text: A phenomenal restaurant well deserving of a Michelin Star - everything was so good - one of the best in London

Name: Kitchen W8
Review_Text: Last night my wife and I celebrated our 40th anniversary. The meal experience was everything we hoped it could be. The food was creative and delicious. The homemade linguini appetizer was very flavorful! The cod and deer courses were wonderful! The service from Allegra and Dipika was exceptional! Anyone reading this should go and experience Kitchen W8 for themselves!

Name: Kitchen W8
Review_Text: Went here for dinner, I certainly hope that the Michelin reviewer returns here soon because there is absolutely no way the service or food here warrants a star. We had a hair in one of our diner's main dish, the service was inattentive at best and disappointingly unimpressive for a restaurant with a Michelin star. At $230 for dinner for 2 I would expect at least good food or good service but neither was provided except for the one chipper fellow who brought the bread and said goodbye on the way out. If only he had been our server perhaps things might have been at least a bit friendlier. My husband had also made the reservation and noted we were celebrating my birthday, they did not acknowledge this though we did see them seat another couple and then awkwardly ask them to move after they had been seated for a bit because another couple was celebrating their anniversary and they wanted that particular table. All in all a very disappointing experience. The best part of the meal was the apricot old fashioned, it is the only thing I would recommend and probably would had had another had the server ever come back and asked if would like another drink.

Name: Kitchen W8
Review_Text:
I wouldn't recommend Kitchen W8.

The Good...

- The servers were friendly. Seemed like really nice people and you could see how they interacted with the other guests. It was really charming.

- The decor. Loved it. Enjoyed the tables, chairs, colors, wall art... All great.

The Bad...

- The food just wasn't great. It was presented beautifully. Some of the most beautifully presented food I've ever experienced. The flavors weren't there. They lacked. It felt like there was much more emphasis on presentation than flavor.

The Ugly...

- I'm shocked this restaurant has a Michelin star. That was the reason we chose Kitchen W8. We went out of our way to visit, and we honestly left disappointed.

- Very overpriced.

Name: Kitchen W8
Review_Text: One of the best meals I have ever had in my entire life. I didn't even know the menu going in, just that it would be good, and it absolutely blew me away. The highlight of my vacation.

Name: Kitchen W8
Review_Text: I wanted to try a Michelin starred restaurant for my 30th birthday and after hours of research, we finally settled on Kitchen W8 and let me tell you, it did NOT disappoint. Upon arrival, we were greeted with a friendly host who handed me a happy birthday card! We got to the table and the server walked us through the menu. We asked a lot of questions and he was extremely knowledgeable and helpful in providing us direction, recommendations and wine pairings. It was a truly memorable experience with impeccable food, delicious drinks, phenomenal service and a clean, modern and classy ambience. Also, they brought me a birthday dessert with a candle. It was such a special meal and I'm so glad I chose to spend my 30th here.

Name: La Trompette
Review_Text: Great food, great drinks, great service. Delightful neighborhood feel for such high end food

Name: Locanda Locatelli
Review_Text: Fantastic food and service. A must dining spot in London for high quality Italian food. Ambiance is perfect for that special night out or for a business meal.

Name: Locanda Locatelli
Review_Text: Service is very professional but not so friendly. Shout out to the wine guy, he was super nice! Food is amazing, has a solid selection of meals. Atmosphere is really boring, no decorations.

Name: Locanda Locatelli
Review_Text: Sadly to report. I used to come to this restaurant often but the management have become vitriolic and rude. I brought a VIP client here and we were shocked to have our food and drink removed. No apology and no communication from the staff. Needless to say my client was disappointed. This is NOT a good place to bring important clients.

Name: Locanda Locatelli
Review_Text: After a ten year hiatus we finally made it a back this summer. The somme recommended a great amarone (quintarelli 2012) which we thoroughly enjoyed.
